name: SLIFE Content Library
description: Age-appropriate, low-reading-level content for Students with Limited or Interrupted Formal Education

slife_overview.definition: Students with Limited or Interrupted Formal Education - newcomers who have had gaps in their schooling due to war, displacement, poverty, or lack of access
slife_overview.alberta_context: Many newcomer students to Alberta, particularly from refugee backgrounds, may have 2+ years below expected grade-level schooling
key_challenges: Limited or no L1 literacy foundation
Age-grade mismatch (older but need foundational instruction)
May need to learn 'how to do school'

content_principles.age_appropriate_topics: Content addresses interests and experiences of older learners
content_principles.low_reading_level: Text is at emergent to early intermediate reading levels
content_principles.visual_support: Heavy use of images, diagrams, and graphic organizers
content_principles.scaffolded: Content builds systematically with clear progression
content_principles.culturally_responsive: Includes diverse perspectives and avoids cultural bias
content_principles.practical_relevance: Connects to real-world needs and daily life

level_1.name: Emergent
level_1.target_students: New to print literacy, any age

level_3.name: Transitional
characteristics: Mix of simple and compound sentences

passages.title: My New School
passages.text: This is my school. It is big. I see many rooms. This is my classroom. My teacher is here. My desk is here. I sit here every day. I am learning.
discussion_questions: What do you see in your classroom?
passages.cultural_note: Schools may be very different from students' prior experiences

passages.title: Getting Food at School
passages.text: It is lunch time. I go to the lunch room. I get in line. I wait my turn. I get a tray. I get food. I find a table. I sit and eat. The food is good.
discussion_questions: What do you eat for lunch?

passages.title: Using the Bus
passages.text: I take the bus to school. The bus is yellow. I wait at the bus stop. The bus comes at 8:00. I get on the bus. I show my bus pass. I find a seat. The bus drives to school. I get off the bus at school. I walk to my class.
discussion_questions: How do you get to school?
What time does your bus come?

passages.title: My Family
passages.text: I have a family. My family is important to me. I live with my mother and father. I have two sisters. My grandmother lives with us too. We help each other. We eat dinner together. We talk about our day. Family is special. I love my family.
passages.cultural_note: Family structures vary; be inclusive of different family compositions

passages.title: Going to the Doctor
passages.text: Sometimes I feel sick. When I am sick, I go to the doctor. First, I call the clinic. I make an appointment. Then I go to the clinic. I sit in the waiting room. A nurse calls my name. The doctor asks questions. The doctor helps me feel better. Medicine can help too.
discussion_questions: When do you go to the doctor?
What do you say when you call the clinic?

passages.title: Shopping for Groceries
passages.text: I go to the grocery store with my family. We make a list before we go. At the store, we get a cart. We walk down the aisles. We find the food on our list. We put the food in the cart. We pay at the checkout. The cashier scans our food. We pay with money or a card. Then we take the bags home.
discussion_questions: How do you pay for groceries?

passages.title: Canada Has Four Seasons
passages.text: Canada has four seasons: spring, summer, fall, and winter. In spring, the snow melts. Flowers start to grow. The weather gets warmer. In summer, it is hot. People go outside and swim. In fall, leaves change color. They turn red, orange, and yellow. The weather gets cooler. In winter, it snows. It is very cold in Alberta. People wear warm coats, hats, and gloves. Each season is different and beautiful.
discussion_questions: How is the weather different from your home country?

passages.title: Getting a Job
passages.text: Many students want a part-time job. A job helps you earn money. First, you need to write a resume. A resume tells about your skills and experience. Then you look for jobs. You can look online or ask at stores. When you find a job you like, you apply. You fill out an application. If they like your application, they call you. You go for an interview. In the interview, they ask you questions. You tell them about yourself. If you do well, they offer you the job!
discussion_questions: What kind of job would you like?

passages.title: Using a Map
passages.text: A map helps you find places. This map shows my neighborhood. The blue lines are streets. The green spaces are parks. The red dot shows where I am. I want to go to the library. I follow the map. I turn left. I walk straight. The library is on the right. Maps are very helpful!

passages.title: Staying Safe Online
passages.text: The internet is useful, but we need to stay safe. Here are some tips. Never share your password. Only talk to people you know. If someone online makes you uncomfortable, tell an adult. Don't click on strange links. They might be dangerous. Be careful what you share. Once you post something, everyone can see it. Use privacy settings on your accounts. If you see something bad, tell a trusted adult. Staying safe online is important.

visual_support: Photographs of real people and places

Schools run on schedules with bells and transitions
